blocks.name: ax-ac
blocks.content: Axiom of Choice. The Axiom of Choice (AC) is usually considered an extension of ZF set theory rather than a proper part of it. It is sometimes considered philosophically controversial because it asserts the existence of a set without telling us what the set is. ZF set theory that includes AC is called ZFC. The unpublished version given here says that given any set ` x ` , there exists a ` y ` that is a collection of unordered pairs, one pair for each nonempty member of ` x ` . One entry in the pair is the member of ` x ` , and the other entry is some arbitrary member of that member of ` x ` . See the rewritten version ~ ac3 for a more detailed explanation. Theorem ~ ac2 shows an equivalent written compactly with restricted quantifiers. This version was specifically crafted to be short when expanded to primitives. Kurt Maes' 5-quantifier version ~ ackm is slightly shorter when the biconditional of ~ ax-ac is expanded into implication and negation. In ~ axac3 we allow the constant ` CHOICE ` to represent the Axiom of Choice; this simplifies the representation of theorems like ~ gchac (the Generalized Continuum Hypothesis implies the Axiom of Choice). Standard textbook versions of AC are derived as ~ ac8 , ~ ac5 , and ~ ac7 . The Axiom of Regularity ~ ax-reg (among others) is used to derive our version from the standard ones; this reverse derivation is shown as theorem ~ dfac2b . Equivalents to AC are the well-ordering theorem ~ weth and Zorn's lemma ~ zorn . See ~ ac4 for comments about stronger versions of AC. In order to avoid uses of ~ ax-reg for derivation of AC equivalents, we provide ~ ax-ac2 (due to Kurt Maes), which is equivalent to the standard AC of textbooks. The derivation of ~ ax-ac2 from ~ ax-ac is shown by theorem ~ axac2 , and the reverse derivation by ~ axac . Therefore, new proofs should normally use ~ ax-ac2 instead. (New usage is discouraged.) (Contributed by NM, 18-Jul-1996.)

  -| diffss(s5, s6)

  -| diffss(s4, s5)

blocks.name: zfac
blocks.content: Axiom of Choice expressed with the fewest number of different variables. The penultimate step shows the logical equivalence to ~ ax-ac . (New usage is discouraged.) (Contributed by NM, 14-Aug-2003.)

  ⊢ ∃(s0, ∀(s1, ∀(s2,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)→ ∃(s3, ∀(s1,(∃(s3,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)∧(s1 ∈ s3 ∧ s3 ∈ s0)))↔ s1 = s3)))))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
} = {
  mpbi(∃(s0, ∀(s1, ∀(s2,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)→ ∃(s3, ∀(s1,(∃(s3,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)∧(s1 ∈ s3 ∧ s3 ∈ s0)))↔ s1 = s3))))))), ∃(s0, ∀(s1, ∀(s2,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)→ ∃(hs2, ∀(hs0,(∃(hs1,((hs0 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ hs1)∧(hs0 ∈ hs1 ∧ hs1 ∈ s0)))↔ hs0 = hs2))))))))
  ax-ac(s0, s1, s2, s3, hs2, hs0, hs1)
  exbii(s0, ∀(s1, ∀(s2,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)→ ∃(hs2, ∀(hs0,(∃(hs1,((hs0 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ hs1)∧(hs0 ∈ hs1 ∧ hs1 ∈ s0)))↔ hs0 = hs2)))))), ∀(s1, ∀(s2,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)→ ∃(s3, ∀(s1,(∃(s3,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)∧(s1 ∈ s3 ∧ s3 ∈ s0)))↔ s1 = s3)))))))
  2albii(s1, s2, ((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)→ ∃(hs2, ∀(hs0,(∃(hs1,((hs0 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ hs1)∧(hs0 ∈ hs1 ∧ hs1 ∈ s0)))↔ hs0 = hs2)))), ((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)→ ∃(s3, ∀(s1,(∃(s3,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)∧(s1 ∈ s3 ∧ s3 ∈ s0)))↔ s1 = s3)))))
  imbi2i((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3), ∃(hs2, ∀(hs0,(∃(hs1,((hs0 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ hs1)∧(hs0 ∈ hs1 ∧ hs1 ∈ s0)))↔ hs0 = hs2))), ∃(s3, ∀(s1,(∃(s3,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)∧(s1 ∈ s3 ∧ s3 ∈ s0)))↔ s1 = s3))))
  cbvexvw(hs2, s3, ∀(hs0,(∃(hs1,((hs0 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ hs1)∧(hs0 ∈ hs1 ∧ hs1 ∈ s0)))↔ hs0 = hs2)), ∀(s1,(∃(s3,((s1 ∈ s2 ∧ s2 ∈ s3)∧(s1 ∈ s3 ∧ s3 ∈ s0)))↔ s1 = s3)))

blocks.content: Axiom of Choice equivalent. By using restricted quantifiers, we can express the Axiom of Choice with a single explicit conjunction. (If you want to figure it out, the rewritten equivalent ~ ac3 is easier to understand.) Note: ~ aceq0 shows the logical equivalence to ~ ax-ac . (New usage is discouraged.) (Contributed by NM, 18-Jul-1996.)

blocks.name: ac3
blocks.content: Axiom of Choice using abbreviations. The logical equivalence to ~ ax-ac can be established by chaining ~ aceq0 and ~ aceq2 . A standard textbook version of AC is derived from this one in ~ dfac2a , and this version of AC is derived from the textbook version in ~ dfac2b , showing their logical equivalence (see ~ dfac2 ). The following sketch will help you understand this version of the axiom. Given any set ` x ` , the axiom says that there exists a ` y ` that is a collection of unordered pairs, one pair for each nonempty member of ` x ` . One entry in the pair is the member of ` x ` , and the other entry is some arbitrary member of that member of ` x ` . Using the Axiom of Regularity, we can show that ` y ` is really a set of _ordered_ pairs, very similar to the ordered pair construction ~ opthreg . The key theorem for this (used in the proof of ~ dfac2b ) is ~ preleq . With this modified definition of ordered pair, it can be seen that ` y ` is actually a choice function on the members of ` x ` . For example, suppose ` x = { { 1 , 2 } , { 1 , 3 } , { 2 , 3 , 4 } } ` . Let us try ` y = { { { 1 , 2 } , 1 } , { { 1 , 3 } , 1 } , ` ` { { 2 , 3 , 4 } , 2 } } ` . For the member (of ` x ` ) ` z = { 1 , 2 } ` , the only assignment to ` w ` and ` v ` that satisfies the axiom is ` w = 1 ` and ` v = { { 1 , 2 } , 1 } ` , so there is exactly one ` w ` as required. We verify the other two members of ` x ` similarly. Thus, ` y ` satisfies the axiom. Using our modified ordered pair definition, we can say that ` y ` corresponds to the choice function ` { <. { 1 , 2 } , 1 >. , <. { 1 , 3 } , 1 >. , ` ` <. { 2 , 3 , 4 } , 2 >. } ` . Of course other choices for ` y ` will also satisfy the axiom, for example ` y = { { { 1 , 2 } , 2 } , { { 1 , 3 } , 1 } , ` ` { { 2 , 3 , 4 } , 4 } } ` . What AC tells us is that there exists at least one such ` y ` , but it doesn't tell us which one. (New usage is discouraged.) (Contributed by NM, 19-Jul-1996.)

blocks.name: ax-ac2
blocks.content: In order to avoid uses of ~ ax-reg for derivation of AC equivalents, we provide ~ ax-ac2 , which is equivalent to the standard AC of textbooks. This appears to be the shortest known equivalent to the standard AC when expressed in terms of set theory primitives. It was found by Kurt Maes as theorem ~ ackm . We removed the leading quantifier to make it slightly shorter, since we have ~ ax-gen available. The derivation of ~ ax-ac2 from ~ ax-ac is shown by theorem ~ axac2 , and the reverse derivation by ~ axac . Note that we use ~ ax-reg to derive ~ ax-ac from ~ ax-ac2 , but not to derive ~ ax-ac2 from ~ ax-ac . (Contributed by NM, 19-Dec-2016.)

  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)

  -| diffss(s1, s2)

  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)

blocks.name: ackm
blocks.content: A remarkable equivalent to the Axiom of Choice that has only five quantifiers (when expanded to ` e. ` , ` = ` primitives in prenex form), discovered and proved by Kurt Maes. This establishes a new record, reducing from 6 to 5 the largest number of quantified variables needed by any ZFC axiom. The ZF-equivalence to AC is shown by theorem ~ dfackm . Maes found this version of AC in April 2004 (replacing a longer version, also with five quantifiers, that he found in November 2003). See Kurt Maes, "A 5-quantifier ( ` e. ` ,=)-expression ZF-equivalent to the Axiom of Choice" ( ~ http://arxiv.org/PS_cache/arxiv/pdf/0705/0705.3162v1.pdf ). The original FOM posts are: ~ http://www.cs.nyu.edu/pipermail/fom/2003-November/007631.html ~ http://www.cs.nyu.edu/pipermail/fom/2003-November/007641.html . (Contributed by NM, 29-Apr-2004.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 17-May-2015.) (Proof modification is discouraged.)

  |- wal(s0, wex(s1, wal(s2, wex(s3, wal(s4, wo(wa(wcel(cv(s1), cv(s0)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1)), wa(wa(wcel(cv(s3), cv(s0)), wn(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s3)))), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s3))))), wa(wn(wcel(cv(s1), cv(s0))), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wa(wa(wcel(cv(s3), cv(s2)), wcel(cv(s3), cv(s1))), wi(wa(wcel(cv(s4), cv(s2)), wcel(cv(s4), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s4), cv(s3))))))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
} = {
  mpbi(wal(s0, wex(s1, wal(s2, wex(s3, wal(s4, wo(wa(wcel(cv(s1), cv(s0)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1)), wa(wa(wcel(cv(s3), cv(s0)), wn(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s3)))), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s3))))), wa(wn(wcel(cv(s1), cv(s0))), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wa(wa(wcel(cv(s3), cv(s2)), wcel(cv(s3), cv(s1))), wi(wa(wcel(cv(s4), cv(s2)), wcel(cv(s4), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s4), cv(s3)))))))))))), wac)

blocks.name: ac4
blocks.content: Equivalent of Axiom of Choice. We do not insist that ` f ` be a function. However, theorem ~ ac5 , derived from this one, shows that this form of the axiom does imply that at least one such set ` f ` whose existence we assert is in fact a function. Axiom of Choice of [TakeutiZaring] p. 83. Takeuti and Zaring call this "weak choice" in contrast to "strong choice" ` E. F A. z ( z =/= (/) -> ( F `` z ) e. z ) ` , which asserts the existence of a universal choice function but requires second-order quantification on (proper) class variable ` F ` and thus cannot be expressed in our first-order formalization. However, it has been shown that ZF plus strong choice is a conservative extension of ZF plus weak choice. See Ulrich Felgner, "Comparison of the axioms of local and universal choice", _Fundamenta Mathematica_, 71, 43-62 (1971). Weak choice can be strengthened in a different direction to choose from a collection of proper classes; see ~ ac6s5 . (Contributed by NM, 21-Jul-1996.)

blocks.name: ac5b
blocks.content: Equivalent of Axiom of Choice. (Contributed by NM, 31-Aug-1999.)
blocks.origin:
thm ac5b(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0) {
  |- wi(wral(s0, c0, wne(cv(s0), emptycls)), wex(s1, wa(wf(cv(s1), c0, cuni(c0)), wral(s0, c0, wcel(cfv(cv(s1), cv(s0)), cv(s0))))))
  -| wcel(c0, universe)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
} = {
  syl2anc(wral(s0, c0, wne(cv(s0), emptycls)), wex(s1, wa(wf(cv(s1), c0, cuni(c0)), wral(s0, c0, wcel(cfv(cv(s1), cv(s0)), cv(s0))))), wcel(cuni(c0), cdm(ccrd)), wn(wcel(emptycls, c0)))
  mp1i(wral(s0, c0, wne(cv(s0), emptycls)), wcel(cuni(c0), cdm(ccrd)), wcel(cuni(c0), universe))
  uniex(c0)
  numth3(cuni(c0), universe)
  mtoi(wral(s0, c0, wne(cv(s0), emptycls)), wcel(emptycls, c0), wne(emptycls, emptycls))
  neirr(emptycls)
  rspccv(s0, c0, emptycls, wne(cv(s0), emptycls), wne(emptycls, emptycls))
  neeq1(cv(s0), emptycls, emptycls)
  ac5num(s1, s0, c0)
  diff.wne.s(s0, emptycls, emptycls)
  diff.emptycls.s(s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm ac5b(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0) {
  ⊢ (∀(s0 ∈ c0, s0 ≠ ∅)→ ∃(s1,((s1 : c0 → ⋃ c0)∧ ∀(s0 ∈ c0,(s1 ` s0)∈ s0))))
  ⊣ c0 ∈ 𝕌
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s1, c0)
} = {
  syl2anc(∀(s0 ∈ c0, s0 ≠ ∅), ∃(s1,((s1 : c0 → ⋃ c0)∧ ∀(s0 ∈ c0,(s1 ` s0)∈ s0))), ⋃ c0 ∈ dom(card), ¬ ∅ ∈ c0)
  mp1i(∀(s0 ∈ c0, s0 ≠ ∅), ⋃ c0 ∈ dom(card), ⋃ c0 ∈ 𝕌)
  uniex(c0)
  numth3(⋃ c0, universe)
  mtoi(∀(s0 ∈ c0, s0 ≠ ∅), ∅ ∈ c0, ∅ ≠ ∅)
  neirr(emptycls)
  rspccv(s0, c0, emptycls, s0 ≠ ∅, ∅ ≠ ∅)
  neeq1(s0, emptycls, emptycls)
  ac5num(s1, s0, c0)
  diff.wne.s(s0, emptycls, emptycls)
  diff.emptycls.s(s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)
}

blocks.name: ac6
blocks.content: Equivalent of Axiom of Choice. This is useful for proving that there exists, for example, a sequence mapping natural numbers to members of a larger set ` B ` , where ` ph ` depends on ` x ` (the natural number) and ` y ` (to specify a member of ` B ` ). A stronger version of this theorem, ~ ac6s , allows ` B ` to be a proper class. (Contributed by NM, 18-Oct-1999.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 27-Aug-2015.)

  sylib(∀(s0 ∈ c0, c1 ≠ ∅), ×(s0 ∈ c0, c1)≠ ∅, ∃(hs0,(hs0[Fn]c0 ∧ ∀(s0 ∈ c0,(hs0 ` s0)∈ c1))))
  ac6c4(s0, hs0, c0, c1)
  bitr2i(∃(hs0,(hs0[Fn]c0 ∧ ∀(s0 ∈ c0,(hs0 ` s0)∈ c1))), ×(s0 ∈ c0, c1)≠ ∅, ∃(hs0, hs0 ∈ ×(s0 ∈ c0, c1)))
  n0(hs0, ×(s0 ∈ c0, c1))
  exbii(hs0, hs0 ∈ ×(s0 ∈ c0, c1), (hs0[Fn]c0 ∧ ∀(s0 ∈ c0,(hs0 ` s0)∈ c1)))
  elixp(s0, hs0, c0, c1)
  vex(hs0)
  ixpn0(s0, c0, c1)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(×(s0 ∈ c0, c1))
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
}

blocks.name: ac6s
blocks.content: Equivalent of Axiom of Choice. Using the Boundedness Axiom ~ bnd2 , we derive this strong version of ~ ac6 that doesn't require ` B ` to be a set. (Contributed by NM, 4-Feb-2004.)
blocks.origin:
thm ac6s(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, wff w0, wff w1) {
  |- wi(wral(s0, c0, wrex(s1, c1, w0)), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, c1), wral(s0, c0, w1))))
  -| wcel(c0, universe)
  -| wi(wceq(cv(s1), cfv(cv(s2), cv(s0))), wb(w0, w1))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c1)
  -| diffsw(s1, w1)
  -| diffsw(s2, w0)
} = {
  3syl(wral(s0, c0, wrex(s1, c1, w0)), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, c1), wral(s0, c0, w1))), wex(hs0, wa(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wral(s0, c0, wrex(s1, cv(hs0), w0)))), wex(hs0, wa(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0)), wral(s0, c0, w1))))))
  bnd2(s0, s1, hs0, c0, c1, w0)
  eximi(hs0, wa(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wral(s0, c0, wrex(s1, cv(hs0), w0))), wa(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0)), wral(s0, c0, w1)))))
  anim2i(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wral(s0, c0, wrex(s1, cv(hs0), w0)), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0)), wral(s0, c0, w1))))
  ac6(s0, s1, s2, c0, cv(hs0), w0, w1)
  vex(hs0)
  exlimiv(hs0, wa(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0)), wral(s0, c0, w1)))), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, c1), wral(s0, c0, w1))))
  imp(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0)), wral(s0, c0, w1))), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, c1), wral(s0, c0, w1))))
  eximdv(s2, wss(cv(hs0), c1), wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0)), wral(s0, c0, w1)), wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, c1), wral(s0, c0, w1)))
  anim1d(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wf(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0)), wral(s0, c0, w1), wf(cv(s2), c0, c1))
  expcom(wss(cv(hs0), c1), wf(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0)), wf(cv(s2), c0, c1))
  fss(cv(s2), c0, cv(hs0), c1)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s1, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s1)
  diff.hs0.w(wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, c1), wral(s0, c0, w1))))
  diff.wss.s(s2, cv(hs0), c1)
  diff.cv.s(s2, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s2, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s2)
}

thm ac6n(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, wff w0, wff w1) {
  |- wi(wal(s0, wi(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wrex(s1, c0, w0))), wrex(s1, c0, wral(s2, c1, w1)))

  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c1)

  -| diffsw(s2, w0)
} = {
  3imtr4i(wal(s0, wi(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wrex(s1, c0, w0))), wrex(s1, c0, wral(s2, c1, w1)), wn(wex(s0, wa(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wral(s1, c0, wn(w0))))), wn(wral(s1, c0, wrex(s2, c1, wn(w1)))))

  ac6s(s1, s2, s0, c0, c1, wn(w1), wn(w0))
  notbid(wceq(cv(s2), cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1))), w1, w0)
  bitri(wal(s0, wi(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wrex(s1, c0, w0))), wn(wex(s0, wa(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wral(s1, c0, wn(w0))))), wal(s0, wi(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wn(wral(s1, c0, wn(w0))))))
  albii(s0, wi(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wrex(s1, c0, w0)), wi(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wn(wral(s1, c0, wn(w0)))))
  imbi2i(wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wrex(s1, c0, w0), wn(wral(s1, c0, wn(w0))))
  dfrex2(s1, c0, w0)
  alinexa(s0, wf(cv(s0), c0, c1), wral(s1, c0, wn(w0)))
  bitri(wrex(s1, c0, wral(s2, c1, w1)), wn(wral(s1, c0, wrex(s2, c1, wn(w1)))), wrex(s1, c0, wn(wrex(s2, c1, wn(w1)))))
  rexbii(s1, c0, wral(s2, c1, w1), wn(wrex(s2, c1, wn(w1))))

thm ac6s2(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, wff w0, wff w1) {
  |- wi(wral(s0, c0, wex(s1, w0)), wex(s2, wa(wfn(cv(s2), c0), wral(s0, c0, w1))))
  -| wcel(c0, universe)

  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
  -| diffsw(s1, w1)
  -| diffsw(s2, w0)
} = {
  sylbir(wral(s0, c0, wex(s1, w0)), wex(s2, wa(wfn(cv(s2), c0), wral(s0, c0, w1))), wral(s0, c0, wrex(s1, universe, w0)))
  ralbii(s0, c0, wrex(s1, universe, w0), wex(s1, w0))
  rexv(s1, w0)
  syl(wral(s0, c0, wrex(s1, universe, w0)), wex(s2, wa(wfn(cv(s2), c0), wral(s0, c0, w1))), wex(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, universe), wral(s0, c0, w1))))
  ac6s(s0, s1, s2, c0, universe, w0, w1)
  eximi(s2, wa(wf(cv(s2), c0, universe), wral(s0, c0, w1)), wa(wfn(cv(s2), c0), wral(s0, c0, w1)))
  anim1i(wf(cv(s2), c0, universe), wral(s0, c0, w1), wfn(cv(s2), c0))

  feq2(cv(hs0), c0, cv(s2), c2)

} = {

}

blocks.name: ac6s5
blocks.content: Generalization of the Axiom of Choice to proper classes. ` B ` is a collection ` B ( x ) ` of nonempty, possible proper classes. Remark after Theorem 10.46 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 98. (Contributed by NM, 27-Mar-2006.)

blocks.name: ac8
blocks.content: An Axiom of Choice equivalent. Given a family ` x ` of mutually disjoint nonempty sets, there exists a set ` y ` containing exactly one member from each set in the family. Theorem 6M(4) of [Enderton] p. 151. (Contributed by NM, 14-May-2004.)

blocks.name: ac9s
blocks.content: An Axiom of Choice equivalent: the infinite Cartesian product of nonempty classes is nonempty. Axiom of Choice (second form) of [Enderton] p. 55 and its converse. This is a stronger version of the axiom in Enderton, with no existence requirement for the family of classes ` B ( x ) ` (achieved via the Collection Principle ~ cp ). (Contributed by NM, 29-Sep-2006.)
